Les mots l'avaient frappée plus fort qu'elle ne l'avait anticipé. Ailleurs. C'était exactement comme elle se sentait. C'était comme si le monde autour d'elle avançait à une vitesse qu'elle ne pourrait jamais atteindre, comme un fantôme regardant depuis la ligne de touche, attendant quelque chose—n'importe quoi—qui la ramènerait dans le flux de la vie.

Elle se leva, le poids de ses pensées écrasant sa poitrine. La pièce semblait suffocante, le silence trop bruyant, trop étouffant. Elle avait besoin de sortir, d'échapper au cycle d'introspection qui semblait l'emprisonner.

En marchant dans les rues de la ville, l'esprit de Meera était un tourbillon de pensées contradictoires. Elle passait devant des visages familiers, mais ils semblaient ne pas la remarquer. Ils étaient pris dans leurs propres mondes, passant d'une tâche à l'autre, leurs vies aussi opaques pour elle qu'elle l'était pour eux.

Elle pensa à *La Métamorphose* de Kafka, à Gregor Samsa, qui se réveilla un jour transformé en une créature si étrange qu'il ne pouvait plus se connecter avec ceux qu'il aimait. Et pourtant, même dans sa forme grotesque, il cherchait à comprendre sa place dans le monde, à trouver du sens dans l'horreur de son existence.

Meera se sentait comme si elle aussi avait subi une transformation, non pas dans son corps, mais dans son âme. Elle n'était plus sûre de qui elle était, ni de pourquoi elle était là, ni s'il y avait un sens à tout cela. Le monde semblait indifférent à son existence, comme une énorme machine insensible qui continuait à tourner pendant qu'elle restait immobile.

Elle passa devant un coin de rue et vit un petit groupe d'enfants riant, leurs voix claires et libres. Pendant un instant, un étrange pincement de désir se fit sentir dans son cœur. Comme leur vie semblait simple, pleine de joie. Ils n'avaient pas encore été accablés par le poids des questions sans réponse.

Meera s'arrêta, soudainement consciente du silence autour d'elle. La ville, les gens, le vacarme incessant de la vie moderne—tout semblait maintenant lointain, comme appartenant à quelqu'un d'autre. Elle ferma les yeux, laissant le bruit du vent remplir ses sens. Pour la première fois depuis des jours, le tic-tac de l'horloge dans sa tête commença à ralentir.

Peut-être que la vie n'a pas de grand sens, pensa-t-elle. Peut-être qu'il ne s'agit pas de trouver des réponses aux questions sans réponse. Peut-être qu'il s'agit simplement d'être. Être dans le moment, même si ce moment semble éphémère, même s'il semble absurde.

El reloj en la pared nunca había sonado tan fuerte para Meera como ahora. Cada tictac resonaba en su pequeño apartamento, un sonido que parecía hacerse más fuerte con cada segundo que pasaba, como si el propio universo se estuviera burlando de su incapacidad para encontrar paz. Estaba sentada junto a la ventana, mirando las luces de la ciudad abajo, cada una parpadeando como una estrella distante que nunca podría alcanzar.

¿Cuántas veces había intentado escapar de este sentimiento? Calmarse con trabajo, socializando, distracciones fugaces. Pero no importaba lo que hiciera, el sentimiento de alienación persistía. No era el tipo de soledad que se cura con una conversación o un fin de semana. Era más profundo—un silencio opresivo que se adhería a cada uno de sus pensamientos, haciéndola sentir como una extraña en su propia vida.

Meera tomó su teléfono, desplazándose sin rumbo por los mensajes en su pantalla. Amigos invitándola a fiestas, colegas discutiendo proyectos, familia preguntando sobre sus planes para las vacaciones. Se suponía que debía sentirse conectada con estas personas, pero, en cambio, le parecían personajes de una historia de la que ya no formaba parte. Sus vidas avanzaban con propósito, mientras que la suya parecía suspendida en una pausa interminable.

Pensó en su última conversación con Ravi, su amigo más cercano. Le había preguntado, con su habitual tono alegre, '¿Cómo va todo? ¿Sigues sintiéndote mal?'

Claro que había mentido. Siempre lo hacía. 'Sí, estoy bien,' dijo, mostrando una sonrisa que no sentía. Pero Ravi, tan perceptivo como siempre, hizo una pausa, entrecerrando los ojos mientras la miraba.

'’Meera, no estás bien. Estás... en otro lugar. Has estado flotando un rato. Es como si estuvieras aquí, pero no realmente aquí.'

Las palabras la golpearon más fuerte de lo que esperaba. En otro lugar. Eso era exactamente lo que sentía. Era como si el mundo a su alrededor avanzara a un ritmo que nunca podría alcanzar, como un fantasma observando desde la línea de banda, esperando algo—cualquier cosa—que la trajera de vuelta al flujo de la vida.

Se levantó, el peso de sus pensamientos aplastando su pecho. La habitación parecía sofocante, el silencio demasiado ruidoso, demasiado asfixiante. Necesitaba salir, escapar del ciclo de introspección que parecía atraparla.

Mientras caminaba por las calles de la ciudad, la mente de Meera era un torbellino de pensamientos contradictorios. Pasaba junto a caras conocidas, pero parecían no notarla. Estaban atrapados en sus propios mundos, saltando de una tarea a otra, sus vidas tan opacas para ella como la suya lo era para ellos.

Pensó en *La metamorfosis* de Kafka, en Gregor Samsa, que se despertó un día transformado en una criatura tan extraña que ya no podía conectar con aquellos a quienes amaba. Y sin embargo, incluso en su forma grotesca, trataba de entender su lugar en el mundo, de encontrar sentido en el horror de su existencia.

Meera sintió que ella también había sufrido una transformación, no en su cuerpo, sino en su alma. Ya no estaba segura de quién era, ni de por qué estaba allí, ni si había algún sentido en todo eso. El mundo parecía indiferente a su existencia, como una enorme máquina insensible que seguía funcionando mientras ella permanecía inmóvil.

Pasó junto a una esquina de la calle y vio un pequeño grupo de niños riendo, sus voces claras y libres. Por un momento, sintió una extraña punzada de deseo en su corazón. Cómo parecía tan simple su vida, llena de alegría. Todavía no habían sido aplastados por el peso de las preguntas sin respuesta.

Meera se detuvo, de repente consciente del silencio a su alrededor. La ciudad, las personas, el bullicio interminable de la vida moderna—todo ahora parecía lejano, como si perteneciera a otra persona. Cerró los ojos, dejando que el sonido del viento llenara sus sentidos. Por primera vez en días, el tic-tac del reloj en su cabeza comenzó a ralentizarse.

Tal vez la vida no tiene un gran sentido, pensó. Tal vez no se trata de encontrar respuestas a las preguntas sin respuesta. Tal vez se trata simplemente de ser. Estar en el momento, incluso si ese momento parece fugaz, incluso si parece absurdo.

Cuando se giró para regresar a casa, las luces de la ciudad ya no parecían tan lejanas. Eran las suyas, después de todo. Al igual que esta vida—fragmentada, incierta, llena de preguntas silenciosas—también era la suya.

El silencio del reloj seguía allí, pero ya no parecía tan opresivo. Era simplemente el ritmo del tiempo, marcando el paso, recordándole que incluso en el silencio, hay vida.

story.en:
The clock on the wall had never seemed louder to Meera than it did now. Each tick echoed in her small apartment, a sound that seemed to grow louder with every passing second, as if the universe itself were mocking her inability to find peace. She sat at the window, staring out at the city lights below, each one flickering like a distant star she could never reach.

How many times had she tried to escape this feeling? To numb herself with work, with socializing, with fleeting distractions? But no matter what she did, the sense of alienation remained. It wasn’t the kind of loneliness that could be cured by a conversation or a weekend getaway. It was deeper—an oppressive silence that clung to her every thought, making her feel like an outsider in her own life.

Meera picked up her phone, scrolling mindlessly through the messages on her screen. Friends inviting her to parties, colleagues discussing projects, family asking about her plans for the holidays. She was supposed to feel connected to these people, but instead, they felt like characters in a story she was no longer part of. Their lives moved with purpose, while hers seemed suspended in a never-ending pause.

She thought of her last conversation with Ravi, her closest friend. He had asked, in his usual cheerful way, 'How’s everything? Still feeling down?'

She had lied, of course. She always did. 'Yeah, I’m fine,' she had said, plastering on a smile she didn’t feel. But Ravi, as perceptive as he was, had paused, his eyes narrowing as he looked at her.

'’Meera, you’re not fine. You’re... somewhere else. You’ve been drifting for a while. It’s like you’re here, but you’re not really here.'

The words had hit her harder than she expected. Somewhere else. That was exactly how she felt. It was as if the world around her was moving at a pace she could never quite match, like a ghost watching from the sidelines, waiting for something—anything—that would pull her back into the fold of life.

She stood up, the weight of her own thoughts pressing down on her. The room felt suffocating, the silence too loud, too overwhelming. She needed to get out, to escape the cycle of introspection that seemed to trap her.

Walking through the streets of the city, Meera’s mind was a whirlwind of conflicting thoughts. She passed familiar faces, but they didn’t seem to register. They were caught in their own worlds, moving from one task to the next, their lives as opaque to her as hers was to them.

She thought of Kafka’s *Metamorphosis*, of Gregor Samsa, who woke one day to find himself transformed into a creature so alien that he could no longer relate to those he loved. And yet, even in his grotesque form, he sought to understand his place in the world, to find meaning in the horror of his existence.

Meera felt as though she, too, had undergone some kind of transformation, not in her body but in her soul. She was no longer sure who she was, or why she was here, or if there was any point to it at all. The world felt indifferent to her existence, like a vast, uncaring machine churning onward while she stood still.

She passed a street corner and saw a small group of children laughing, their voices pure and free. For a moment, a strange pang of longing tugged at her heart. How simple their lives seemed, how full of joy. They had not yet been burdened with the weight of questions that had no answers.

Meera stopped, suddenly aware of the quietness around her. The city, the people, the endless noise of modern life—it all felt distant now, like it belonged to someone else. She closed her eyes, letting the sound of the wind fill her senses. For the first time in days, the ticking of the clock in her head seemed to slow.

Maybe there was no grand meaning to life, she thought. Maybe it wasn’t about finding answers to the unanswerable questions. Maybe it was simply about being. Being in the moment, even if that moment felt fleeting, even if it felt absurd.

As she turned back toward home, the city’s lights no longer seemed so distant. They were hers, after all. Just as this life—fragmented, uncertain, and full of quiet questions—was hers too.

The silence of the clock was still there, but it no longer felt so oppressive. It was simply the rhythm of time, ticking away, reminding her that even in the stillness, there was life.
story.rs:
Tihotno otkucavanje sata na zidu nikada nije zvučalo glasnije Meeri nego sada. Svaki otkucaj odjekivao je u njenom malom stanu, zvuk koji je delovao sve glasnije sa svakim trenutkom, kao da je sam univerzum zadirkivao njen nesposobnost da pronađe mir. Sedeći na prozoru, gledala je gradsku svetlost ispod, svaka svetiljka treperila kao dalja zvezda koju nikada nije mogla da dostigne.

Koliko puta je pokušala da pobegne od ovog osećaja? Da umiri sebe poslom, društvom, prolaznim distrakcijama? Ali bez obzira na to šta je radila, osećaj otuđenosti je ostajao. To nije bila vrsta usamljenosti koja se mogla izlečiti razgovorom ili vikend-odmorom. Bilo je dublje—opresivna tišina koja se lepkala za svaki njen misao, čineći da se oseća kao stranac u svom sopstvenom životu.

Meera je uzela telefon, bez cilja pomerajući ekran, čitajući poruke. Prijatelji je pozivaju na žurke, kolege raspravljaju o projektima, porodica pita o planovima za praznike. Trebalo je da se oseća povezano sa tim ljudima, ali umesto toga, oni su joj delovali kao likovi u priči iz koje nije više deo. Njihovi životi su se kretali sa smislom, dok je njen delovao kao da je suspendovan u beskrajnoj pauzi.

Setila se poslednjeg razgovora sa Ravijem, njenim najbližim prijateljem. Pitao je, u svom uobičajenom veselom tonu, 'Kako je sve? I dalje se osećaš loše?'

Naravno da je slagala. Uvek je. 'Da, dobro sam,' rekla je, stavljajući osmeh koji nije osećala. Ali Ravi, koliko je bio perceptivan, zastao je, sužavajući oči dok ju je gledao.

'’Meera, nisi dobro. Ti si... negde drugde. Plutaš već neko vreme. Kao da si tu, ali nisi stvarno tu.'

Reči su je pogodile jače nego što je očekivala. Negde drugde. To je upravo ono kako se osećala. Kao da svet oko nje ide brzinom koju ona nikada ne bi mogla da dostigne, kao duh koji posmatra sa strane, čekajući nešto—bilo šta—što bi je povuklo nazad u tok života.

Ustala je, težina vlastitih misli pritisnula je njene grudi. Soba je delovala zagušljivo, tišina previše glasna, previše obuhvatna. Morala je da izađe, da pobegne od ciklusa introspekcije koji je delovao kao da je zarobio.

Šetajući ulicama grada, Meera je bila vrtlog protivrečnih misli. Prolazila je pored poznatih lica, ali nisu delovali kao da je registruju. Bili su zarobljeni u sopstvenim svetovima, prelazeći iz jednog zadatka u drugi, njihovi životi bili su opaki za nju kao što je njen bio za njih.

Pomislila je na Kafkin *Preobražaj*, na Gregora Zamzu, koji se jednog dana probudio i našao da je postao stvorenje toliko strano da više nije mogao da se poveže sa onima koje je voleo. Ipak, čak i u svom grotesknom obliku, pokušavao je da razjasni svoje mesto u svetu, da pronađe smisao u užasu svog postojanja.

Meera je osetila kao da je i ona prošla kroz neku vrstu preobražaja, ne u svom telu, već u svojoj duši. Više nije bila sigurna ko je, niti zašto je ovde, niti da li postoji neki smisao u svemu tome. Svet je delovao ravnodušno prema njenom postojanju, kao ogromna, neosetljiva mašina koja nastavlja da se vrti dok je ona stajala.

Prolazila je pored ugla ulice i videla malu grupu dece kako se smeje, njihovi glasovi su bili čisti i slobodni. Na trenutak je osetila čudnu žudnju u svom srcu. Kako su njihovi životi delovali jednostavno, kako puni radosti. Još nisu bili opterećeni težinom pitanja na koja nema odgovora.

Meera je stala, iznenada svesna tišine oko sebe. Grad, ljudi, beskrajna buka modernog života—sve je sada delovalo daleko, kao da pripada nekome drugom. Zatvorila je oči, dopuštajući da zvuk vetra popuni njena čula. Prvi put u poslednjih nekoliko dana, otkucavanje sata u njenoj glavi počelo je da usporava.

Možda život nema veliki smisao, pomislila je. Možda nije stvar u tome da se pronađu odgovori na neodgovoriva pitanja. Možda je jednostavno stvar u tome da se bude. Biti u trenutku, čak i ako taj trenutak deluje prolazno, čak i ako deluje besmisleno.

Kada se okrenula i krenula nazad prema domu, gradska svetla više nisu delovala tako daleko. Bila su njena, ipak. Kao i ovaj život—fragmentiran, nesiguran, pun tihih pitanja—bio je njen takođe.

Tišina sata je i dalje bila tu, ali više nije delovala tako opresivno. Bilo je to jednostavno ritam vremena, otkucavajući, podsećajući je da čak i u tišini, postoji život.

She stood up, the weight of her own thoughts pressing down on her. The room felt suffocating, the silence too loud, too overwhelming. She needed to get out, to escape the cycle of introspection that seemed to trap her.

Walking through the streets of the city, Meera’s mind was a whirlwind of conflicting thoughts. She passed familiar faces, but they didn’t seem to register. They were caught in their own worlds, moving from one task to the next, their lives as opaque to her as hers was to them.

She thought of Kafka’s *Metamorphosis*, of Gregor Samsa, who woke one day to find himself transformed into a creature so alien that he could no longer relate to those he loved. And yet, even in his grotesque form, he sought to understand his place in the world, to find meaning in the horror of his existence.

Meera felt as though she, too, had undergone some kind of transformation, not in her body but in her soul. She was no longer sure who she was, or why she was here, or if there was any point to it at all. The world felt indifferent to her existence, like a vast, uncaring machine churning onward while she stood still.

She passed a street corner and saw a small group of children laughing, their voices pure and free. For a moment, a strange pang of longing tugged at her heart. How simple their lives seemed, how full of joy. They had not yet been burdened with the weight of questions that had no answers.

Meera stopped, suddenly aware of the quietness around her. The city, the people, the endless noise of modern life—it all felt distant now, like it belonged to someone else. She closed her eyes, letting the sound of the wind fill her senses. For the first time in days, the ticking of the clock in her head seemed to slow.

Maybe there was no grand meaning to life, she thought. Maybe it wasn’t about finding answers to the unanswerable questions. Maybe it was simply about being. Being in the moment, even if that moment felt fleeting, even if it felt absurd.

As she turned back toward home, the city’s lights no longer seemed so distant. They were hers, after all. Just as this life—fragmented, uncertain, and full of quiet questions—was hers too.

The silence of the clock was still there, but it no longer felt so oppressive. It was simply the rhythm of time, ticking away, reminding her that even in the stillness, there was life.
story.ru:
Часы на стене никогда не казались Мира такой громкими, как сейчас. Каждый тик эхом отдавался в её маленькой квартире, звук, который, казалось, становился всё громче с каждой секундой, словно сама вселенная насмехалась над её неспособностью найти покой. Она сидела у окна, глядя на огни города внизу, каждый из которых мерцал, как далёкая звезда, которую она никогда не сможет достичь.

Сколько раз она пыталась сбежать от этого чувства? Заглушить его работой, общением, мимолётными развлечениями? Но что бы она ни делала, чувство отчуждения оставалось. Это была не та одиночество, которое можно вылечить разговором или поездкой на выходные. Это было глубже — угнетающая тишина, охватывающая каждую её мысль, заставляя её чувствовать себя чужой в собственной жизни.

Мира взяла телефон и бездумно пролистывала сообщения на экране. Друзья приглашали её на вечеринки, коллеги обсуждали проекты, семья спрашивала о планах на праздники. Она должна была чувствовать связь с этими людьми, но вместо этого они казались персонажами истории, частью которой она больше не была. Их жизни двигались с целью, в то время как её казалась застывшей в бесконечной паузе.

Она вспомнила последний разговор с Рави, её самым близким другом. Он спросил, как обычно жизнерадостно: 'Как дела? Всё ещё грустно?'

Она, конечно, солгала. Она всегда так делала. 'Да, у меня всё хорошо,' — ответила она, натянув улыбку, которой не чувствовала. Но Рави, такой проницательный, как всегда, замолчал, прищурив глаза, глядя на неё.

'Мира, ты не в порядке. Ты... где-то не здесь. Ты давно как будто плывёшь по течению. Ты здесь, но как будто тебя на самом деле нет.'

Эти слова ударили её сильнее, чем она ожидала. 'Где-то не здесь.' Это было именно то, как она себя чувствовала. Будто мир вокруг неё двигался с такой скоростью, с которой она никогда не могла бы поспевать, как призрак, наблюдающий со стороны и ждущий чего-то — чего угодно, что вернёт её в жизнь.

Она встала, тяжесть собственных мыслей давила на неё. Комната казалась душной, тишина — слишком громкой, слишком подавляющей. Ей нужно было выйти, сбежать из этого круга самокопания, который казался ловушкой.

Гуляя по улицам города, мысли Мира были вихрем противоречий. Она проходила мимо знакомых лиц, но они, казалось, не регистрировались в её сознании. Они были поглощены своими мирами, переходя от одной задачи к другой, их жизни были для неё такими же непроницаемыми, как и её для них.

Она вспомнила 'Превращение' Кафки, о Грегоре Замзе, который однажды проснулся, превратившись в существо настолько чуждое, что он больше не мог быть близким тем, кого любил. И всё же, даже в своей уродливой форме, он стремился понять своё место в мире, найти смысл в ужасе своего существования.

Мира чувствовала, будто она тоже претерпела какую-то трансформацию, не в теле, а в душе. Она больше не была уверена, кто она, почему она здесь, и есть ли в этом какой-то смысл вообще. Мир казался равнодушным к её существованию, как огромная, безразличная машина, которая продолжала работать, пока она стояла на месте.

Она прошла угол улицы и увидела небольшую группу детей, смеющихся, их голоса были чистыми и свободными. На мгновение странное чувство тоски сжало её сердце. Как просты их жизни, как полны радости. Они ещё не обременены грузом вопросов, на которые нет ответов.

Мира остановилась, внезапно осознавая тишину вокруг себя. Город, люди, бесконечный шум современной жизни — всё это теперь казалось далёким, будто оно принадлежало кому-то другому. Она закрыла глаза, позволяя ветру заполнить её чувства. Впервые за несколько дней тиканье часов в её голове, казалось, замедлилось.

Может быть, в жизни нет никакого великого смысла, подумала она. Может быть, дело не в том, чтобы найти ответы на вопросы без ответов. Может быть, дело просто в том, чтобы быть. Быть в моменте, даже если этот момент кажется мимолётным, даже если он кажется абсурдным.

Когда она повернулась обратно к дому, огни города больше не казались такими далёкими. Они были её, в конце концов. Так же как эта жизнь — фрагментированная, неопределённая и полная тихих вопросов — была её тоже.

Тишина часов всё ещё была там, но она больше не казалась такой угнетающей. Это был просто ритм времени, который шёл своим чередом, напоминая ей, что даже в тишине есть жизнь.
story.es:
El reloj en la pared nunca le había parecido más ruidoso a Meera que ahora. Cada tic resonaba en su pequeño apartamento, un sonido que parecía crecer más fuerte con cada segundo que pasaba, como si el universo mismo se burlara de su incapacidad para encontrar paz. Estaba sentada junto a la ventana, mirando las luces de la ciudad abajo, cada una parpadeando como una estrella lejana a la que nunca podría llegar. 

¿Cuántas veces había intentado escapar de esa sensación? Ahogarla con trabajo, con interacción, con distracciones pasajeras. Pero sin importar lo que hiciera, el sentimiento de desconexión persistía. No era una soledad que pudiera curarse con una charla o un viaje de fin de semana. Era algo más profundo: un silencio opresivo que impregnaba cada pensamiento, haciéndola sentir como una extraña en su propia vida. 

Meera tomó su teléfono y comenzó a desplazarse sin pensar a través de los mensajes en la pantalla. Amigos la invitaban a fiestas, colegas discutían proyectos, la familia preguntaba sobre planes para las fiestas. Debería sentirse conectada con estas personas, pero en lugar de eso, le parecían personajes de una historia de la que ya no formaba parte. Sus vidas avanzaban con propósito, mientras que la suya parecía estar detenida en una pausa interminable.

Recordó la última conversación con Ravi, su amigo más cercano. Él había preguntado, como siempre lleno de energía: '¿Cómo estás? ¿Sigues triste?'

Por supuesto, mintió. Siempre lo hacía. 'Sí, estoy bien,' respondió, forzando una sonrisa que no sentía. Pero Ravi, tan perceptivo como siempre, se quedó en silencio, entrecerrando los ojos mientras la miraba.

'No estás bien, Meera. No estás aquí. Has estado flotando durante mucho tiempo. Estás aquí, pero es como si no estuvieras realmente.'

Esas palabras la golpearon más fuerte de lo que esperaba. 'No estás aquí.' Era exactamente como se sentía. Como si el mundo a su alrededor se moviera a una velocidad que ella nunca podría alcanzar, como un fantasma mirando desde el exterior, esperando algo — cualquier cosa — que la devolviera a la vida.

Se levantó, sintiendo el peso de sus propios pensamientos. La habitación parecía sofocante, el silencio demasiado fuerte, demasiado opresivo. Necesitaba salir, escapar de ese ciclo de introspección que parecía una trampa.

Mientras caminaba por las calles de la ciudad, sus pensamientos eran un torbellino de contradicciones. Pasaba junto a rostros familiares, pero estos no parecían registrarse en su conciencia. Estaban inmersos en sus propios mundos, moviéndose de una tarea a otra, sus vidas eran tan impenetrables para ella como la suya lo era para ellos.

Recordó 'La metamorfosis' de Kafka, sobre Gregor Samsa, que un día despertó transformado en una criatura tan extraña que ya no podía conectarse con aquellos que amaba. Y, sin embargo, incluso en su forma grotesca, buscaba encontrar su lugar en el mundo, encontrar sentido en el horror de su existencia.

Meera sentía que también había sufrido una transformación, no en su cuerpo, sino en su alma. Ya no estaba segura de quién era, de por qué estaba aquí, y si todo esto tenía algún sentido. El mundo parecía indiferente a su existencia, como una enorme máquina impasible que continuaba funcionando mientras ella permanecía inmóvil.

Dobló la esquina de la calle y vio a un pequeño grupo de niños riendo, sus voces eran puras y libres. Por un momento, un sentimiento extraño de añoranza apretó su corazón. Qué simples eran sus vidas, qué llenas de alegría. Aún no estaban cargados con el peso de preguntas sin respuesta.

Meera se detuvo, dándose cuenta de repente del silencio a su alrededor. La ciudad, las personas, el ruido interminable de la vida moderna — todo eso ahora parecía distante, como si perteneciera a alguien más. Cerró los ojos, permitiendo que el viento llenara sus sentidos. Por primera vez en días, el tic del reloj en su cabeza parecía ralentizarse.

Tal vez no había un gran propósito en la vida, pensó. Tal vez no se trataba de encontrar respuestas a preguntas sin respuesta. Tal vez simplemente se trataba de estar. Estar en el momento, incluso si ese momento se sentía fugaz, incluso si parecía absurdo.

Cuando se dio la vuelta para regresar a casa, las luces de la ciudad ya no parecían tan distantes. Eran suyas, después de todo. Al igual que esta vida — fragmentada, incierta y llena de preguntas silenciosas — también era suya.

El silencio del reloj seguía ahí, pero ya no parecía tan opresivo. Era simplemente el ritmo del tiempo que avanzaba, recordándole que incluso en el silencio, hay vida.

story.en:
The dense jungle was alive with the sounds of nature—birds chirping, leaves rustling, and somewhere in the distance, the faint roar of a waterfall. For Rayna, however, the forest was alive in a way few could understand. Every sound, every whisper of the wind, carried with it impressions of things unseen, a gift—or curse—she had carried since childhood.

They called it ESP, extrasensory perception. Rayna called it the 'Echo.' It wasn’t just hearing or seeing; it was *feeling* the remnants of thoughts, emotions, and sometimes, fragments of memories left behind by others. Her grandmother had called her a 'seer,' but Rayna saw herself more as an unwilling participant in the world's secrets.

She had always avoided using her ability, but today was different. Today, she had no choice. Her younger brother, Kiran, had vanished three days ago during their trek through the jungle, and every search party had returned empty-handed. The authorities wanted to call off the search, dismissing it as another tragic accident. But Rayna knew better. Kiran was alive. She could *feel* him.

Standing at the edge of the trail, Rayna closed her eyes and let the Echo guide her. The forest seemed to breathe with her, a soft hum of life and energy vibrating beneath her feet. Images flickered in her mind like a fading filmstrip—Kiran’s laughter, the smell of the fire they had shared the night before his disappearance, and then... fear. A deep, primal fear that didn’t belong to her but was as vivid as her own memories.

She opened her eyes and began walking. The Echo pulled her deeper into the jungle, away from the marked trails and into the unknown. Every step felt like a gamble, but the urgency in her chest pushed her forward. Her senses were heightened, the air electric with possibilities. There were whispers in the leaves, not of words but of feelings—panic, desperation, and something else. Something ancient.

Rayna pushed past the underbrush until she reached a clearing. At its center stood a monolithic stone, covered in vines and etched with symbols she didn’t recognize. As she approached, the Echo surged within her, flooding her mind with fragmented visions. A group of people in robes, chanting under the moonlight. Kiran, struggling as he was led toward the stone. And then, darkness.

The visions faded, leaving her breathless. She touched the stone, and it was as if the jungle itself had been holding its breath. A low hum resonated through the ground, and suddenly, the symbols on the stone began to glow faintly. The Echo surged again, more powerful than ever, overwhelming her with a single word: *Portal.*

Rayna didn’t understand, but she didn’t need to. Her instincts took over, and she pressed her hand against the glowing symbols. The ground beneath her feet trembled, and a fissure of light opened at the base of the stone. Without hesitation, she stepped through.

The world shifted. One moment, she was in the jungle; the next, she was standing in a vast cavern illuminated by bioluminescent crystals. The air was cooler here, and the hum she had felt earlier was now a symphony of energy. In the center of the cavern, Kiran was bound to an altar, unconscious but alive.

Rayna ran to him, but as she approached, a figure stepped out from the shadows. It was a woman, tall and cloaked, with eyes that seemed to pierce through Rayna’s soul.

'You shouldn’t be here,' the woman said, her voice echoing unnaturally. 'The boy carries the mark. He is the key to the gateway.'

Rayna didn’t understand what the woman meant, but she didn’t care. She reached for Kiran, only to be stopped by an invisible force that threw her back. The woman raised her hands, and the crystals around the cavern began to pulse with light.

But Rayna wasn’t about to give up. The Echo surged within her, stronger than ever. She focused on the energy in the room, feeling its patterns, its rhythm. She didn’t know how she did it, but she reached out with her mind and redirected the flow of energy. The invisible barrier shattered, and the woman staggered back, her control broken.

Rayna rushed to Kiran and untied him. As he stirred, the cavern began to collapse, the energy destabilized by Rayna’s interference. She pulled her brother to his feet, and together they ran toward the portal, narrowly escaping as the cavern caved in behind them.

Back in the jungle, the siblings collapsed to the ground, breathing heavily. Kiran looked at her, his eyes wide with disbelief. 'How did you find me?' he asked.

Rayna smiled faintly. 'I just listened,' she said, her voice soft. 'The Echo never lies.'

As they made their way back to the trail, Rayna couldn’t shake the feeling that this was only the beginning. The Echo had shown her a world beyond her understanding, and she knew it wouldn’t let her walk away so easily. But for now, she was content. She had found her brother, and that was all that mattered.

For now.
story.es:
La densa jungla estaba viva con los sonidos de la naturaleza: el canto de los pájaros, el susurro de las hojas y, a lo lejos, el leve rugido de una cascada. Para Rayna, sin embargo, el bosque estaba vivo de una manera que pocos podían entender. Cada sonido, cada susurro del viento, traía consigo impresiones de cosas no vistas, un don—o maldición—que había cargado desde la infancia.

Lo llamaban PES, percepción extrasensorial. Rayna lo llamaba 'El Eco.' No era solo escuchar o ver; era *sentir* los restos de pensamientos, emociones y, a veces, fragmentos de recuerdos dejados por otros. Su abuela la había llamado 'vidente,' pero Rayna se veía más como una participante involuntaria en los secretos del mundo.

Siempre había evitado usar su habilidad, pero hoy era diferente. Hoy no tenía otra opción. Su hermano menor, Kiran, había desaparecido hacía tres días durante su excursión por la jungla, y todos los equipos de búsqueda habían regresado con las manos vacías. Las autoridades querían cancelar la búsqueda, descartándolo como otro trágico accidente. Pero Rayna sabía que Kiran estaba vivo. Podía *sentirlo.*

Parada al borde del sendero, Rayna cerró los ojos y dejó que el Eco la guiara. El bosque parecía respirar con ella, un suave zumbido de vida y energía vibrando bajo sus pies. Imágenes parpadeaban en su mente como una película desvaneciéndose: la risa de Kiran, el olor del fuego que habían compartido la noche antes de su desaparición, y luego... miedo. Un miedo profundo, primitivo, que no le pertenecía, pero que era tan vívido como sus propios recuerdos.

Abrió los ojos y comenzó a caminar. El Eco la llevaba más adentro de la jungla, lejos de los senderos marcados y hacia lo desconocido. Cada paso se sentía como una apuesta, pero la urgencia en su pecho la empujaba hacia adelante. Sus sentidos estaban agudizados, el aire eléctrico con posibilidades. Había susurros en las hojas, no de palabras, sino de sentimientos: pánico, desesperación y algo más. Algo antiguo.

Rayna apartó la maleza hasta que llegó a un claro. En el centro se erguía una piedra monolítica, cubierta de enredaderas y grabada con símbolos que no reconocía. Al acercarse, el Eco surgió dentro de ella, inundando su mente con visiones fragmentadas. Un grupo de personas con túnicas, cantando bajo la luz de la luna. Kiran, luchando mientras lo llevaban hacia la piedra. Y luego, oscuridad.

Las visiones se desvanecieron, dejándola sin aliento. Tocó la piedra, y fue como si la jungla misma hubiera contenido el aliento. Un zumbido bajo resonó por el suelo, y de repente, los símbolos en la piedra comenzaron a brillar tenuemente. El Eco surgió de nuevo, más fuerte que nunca, abrumándola con una sola palabra: *Portal.*

Rayna no entendía, pero no lo necesitaba. Sus instintos tomaron el control, y presionó su mano contra los símbolos brillantes. El suelo bajo sus pies tembló, y una fisura de luz se abrió en la base de la piedra. Sin dudarlo, atravesó el portal.

El mundo cambió. Un momento estaba en la jungla; al siguiente, estaba en una vasta caverna iluminada por cristales bioluminiscentes. El aire era más fresco aquí, y el zumbido que había sentido antes ahora era una sinfonía de energía. En el centro de la caverna, Kiran estaba atado a un altar, inconsciente pero vivo.

Rayna corrió hacia él, pero al acercarse, una figura salió de las sombras. Era una mujer, alta y con una capa, con ojos que parecían atravesar el alma de Rayna.

'No deberías estar aquí,' dijo la mujer, su voz resonando de manera antinatural. 'El chico lleva la marca. Es la llave del portal.'

Rayna no entendía lo que la mujer quería decir, pero no le importaba. Intentó alcanzar a Kiran, solo para ser detenida por una fuerza invisible que la arrojó hacia atrás. La mujer levantó las manos, y los cristales alrededor de la caverna comenzaron a pulsar con luz.

Pero Rayna no iba a rendirse. El Eco surgió dentro de ella, más fuerte que nunca. Se concentró en la energía de la sala, sintiendo sus patrones, su ritmo. No sabía cómo lo hizo, pero alcanzó la energía con su mente y redirigió su flujo. La barrera invisible se rompió, y la mujer retrocedió tambaleándose, su control roto.

Rayna corrió hacia Kiran y lo desató. Mientras él despertaba, la caverna comenzó a colapsar, la energía desestabilizada por la interferencia de Rayna. Lo ayudó a levantarse, y juntos corrieron hacia el portal, escapando por poco mientras la caverna se derrumbaba tras ellos.

De vuelta en la jungla, los hermanos se desplomaron en el suelo, respirando con dificultad. Kiran la miró, con los ojos abiertos de incredulidad. '¿Cómo me encontraste?' preguntó.

Rayna sonrió débilmente. 'Solo escuché,' dijo en voz baja. 'El Eco nunca miente.'

Mientras volvían al sendero, Rayna no podía sacudirse la sensación de que esto era solo el comienzo. El Eco le había mostrado un mundo más allá de su entendimiento, y sabía que no la dejaría irse tan fácilmente. Pero por ahora, estaba satisfecha. Había encontrado a su hermano, y eso era todo lo que importaba.

Por ahora.

But Rayna wasn’t about to give up. The Echo surged within her, stronger than ever. She focused on the energy in the room, feeling its patterns, its rhythm. She didn’t know how she did it, but she reached out with her mind and redirected the flow of energy. The invisible barrier shattered, and the woman staggered back, her control broken.

Rayna rushed to Kiran and untied him. As he stirred, the cavern began to collapse, the energy destabilized by Rayna’s interference. She pulled her brother to his feet, and together they ran toward the portal, narrowly escaping as the cavern caved in behind them.

Back in the jungle, the siblings collapsed to the ground, breathing heavily. Kiran looked at her, his eyes wide with disbelief. 'How did you find me?' he asked.

Rayna smiled faintly. 'I just listened,' she said, her voice soft. 'The Echo never lies.'

As they made their way back to the trail, Rayna couldn’t shake the feeling that this was only the beginning. The Echo had shown her a world beyond her understanding, and she knew it wouldn’t let her walk away so easily. But for now, she was content. She had found her brother, and that was all that mattered.

For now.

Dear Friend,

The journey to understand the world often feels like gazing at a deep, endless well. You think you see the bottom, but upon closer inspection, it’s only a reflection of yourself staring back. I have pondered this thought every day since the night I met the philosopher.

It was a quiet evening; the stars were scattered across the sky like fragments of shattered glass. I had wandered into a village at the edge of the desert, searching for answers about the universe’s grand design. The villagers spoke of a wise philosopher who lived in a modest hut under a solitary tree. Eager for enlightenment, I ventured to meet them.

The philosopher greeted me with the warmth of someone who had long ago ceased judging the world. Their small home was filled with books, maps, and sketches of constellations. Over tea, they spoke of the nature of existence. "What you see," they said, "is but a layer of reality. Beneath it, there is another, and another still."

I asked, "But what lies beneath all these layers? What is the foundation of it all?"

They smiled, enigmatic yet kind. "Imagine a great turtle," they said. "The world rests upon its back. But what supports the turtle? Another turtle. And below that? Another turtle. It’s turtles all the way down."

At first, I laughed, thinking it a jest. But the more I considered their words, the more profound they became. The idea was not about literal turtles, of course, but about the infinite regress of questions. For every answer we uncover, there lies another question beneath it. The universe, in its vastness, refuses to be fully known.

I stayed with the philosopher for several days, discussing everything from the movement of the stars to the whispers of the desert wind. They taught me that knowledge is not a destination but a journey—a never-ending quest that mirrors the infinite layers of existence.

Before I left, the philosopher gave me a small, intricately carved stone. "This," they said, "is a reminder. When you feel lost in the vastness of life’s questions, hold this stone. It is heavy, yet it is small—just like our understanding of the world."

Now, as I sit under a canopy of stars, writing this letter, I feel the weight of that stone in my pocket. It is both comforting and humbling, a symbol of the mysteries that surround us and the journey we all share to seek the answers, even if they remain forever just out of reach.

With curiosity and wonder,
Tanmay
story.rs:
Dragi prijatelju,

Putovanje ka razumevanju sveta često izgleda kao gledanje u dubok, beskrajan bunar. Misliš da vidiš dno, ali kada pogledaš pažljivije, to je samo tvoj odraz koji gleda nazad. Razmišljao sam o tome svakog dana od noći kada sam upoznao filozofa.

Bila je tiha večer; zvezde su bile razbacane po nebu poput fragmenata slomljenog stakla. Zalutao sam u selo na ivici pustinje, tražeći odgovore o velikom dizajnu univerzuma. Seljani su pričali o mudrom filozofu koji je živeo u skromnoj kolibi ispod samotnog drveta. Željan prosvetljenja, krenuo sam da ga upoznam.

Filozof me je dočekao s toplinom nekoga ko je odavno prestao da sudi svetu. Njegov mali dom bio je ispunjen knjigama, mapama i skicama sazvežđa. Uz čaj, govorio je o prirodi postojanja. "Ono što vidiš," rekao je, "samo je jedan sloj stvarnosti. Ispod njega je drugi, i još jedan ispod toga."

Pitao sam: "Ali šta leži ispod svih tih slojeva? Šta je osnova svega?"

Osmehnuo se, zagonetan, ali ljubazan. "Zamisli veliku kornjaču," rekao je. "Svet počiva na njenim leđima. Ali šta podržava kornjaču? Druga kornjača. A ispod nje? Još jedna kornjača. To su kornjače do samog dna."

U početku sam se nasmejao, misleći da je šala. Ali što sam više razmišljao o njegovim rečima, postajale su dublje. Ideja nije bila o doslovnim kornjačama, naravno, već o beskonačnom nizu pitanja. Za svaki odgovor koji otkrijemo, ispod njega se nalazi još jedno pitanje. Univerzum, u svojoj ogromnosti, odbija da bude potpuno poznat.

Ostao sam kod filozofa nekoliko dana, raspravljajući o svemu, od kretanja zvezda do šapata pustinjskog vetra. Naučio me je da znanje nije odredište, već putovanje—nikada završena potraga koja odražava beskonačne slojeve postojanja.

Pre nego što sam otišao, filozof mi je dao mali, fino izrezbaren kamen. "Ovo," rekao je, "je podsetnik. Kada se osećaš izgubljenim u prostranstvu životnih pitanja, drži ovaj kamen. On je težak, ali je mali—baš kao i naše razumevanje sveta."

Sada, dok sedim pod zvezdanim svodom i pišem ovo pismo, osećam težinu tog kamena u džepu. On je i utešan i ponizan, simbol misterija koje nas okružuju i putovanja koje svi delimo u potrazi za odgovorima, čak i ako oni zauvek ostanu izvan našeg dosega.

S radoznalošću i čudom,
Tanmay

story.en:
11:44 PM... 505... smoke signals.
Everything feels clear, yet blurred—like looking through a fogged-up window at something you once knew by heart.

I had a dream. A rare one. A happy one—though laced with something somber, something aching beneath the surface.

She was there. Back again, as if time had rewound itself. We were all working together, building something in my world, in my present. It felt natural, effortless. Like she had never left. It was her first day, and I was the one guiding her, making sure she felt at home, making sure she understood the heart of it all—our work, our vision, our purpose.

They were both there.
And for the first time in so long, I was happy. Truly, deeply happy.

I told myself I wouldn’t let her go this time.
Not again.
Not because of my own thoughts, my own doubts, my own self-inflicted distance.
Never again.

But then I woke up.

And reality hit like a cold, silent wave.
She’s already gone. Has been for months.

And somehow, waking up from that dream was worse than the loss itself.

For a moment, I just lay there—afraid, disoriented. I wanted to reach for my phone, to call someone, to say something, anything. But the realization crept in, slow and cruel: there was no one to call.

I wished I could.
I wished someone would understand.
I always thought that, if nothing else, I would carry the people I love with me down this road, that their presence—real or not—would echo in my steps.

But that dream, and the unbearable silence that followed, made me question everything.

Will I?

Once upon a time, in a faraway kingdom, there was a powerful tsar who had a magnificent garden filled with all sorts of beautiful flowers and rare trees. The pride of the garden was the Firebird, a magical creature with feathers that glowed like flames. Every night, the Firebird would come to the garden to feast on the golden apples, but no one could catch it. The tsar's youngest son, Prince Ivan, decided to embark on a quest to capture the Firebird. With the help of a wise wolf, Ivan faced many challenges, including battling a wicked sorcerer and rescuing a princess. In the end, Ivan captured the Firebird and brought it back to his father, earning his place as the rightful heir to the throne.
story.РУ: Давным-давно в далеком царстве был могущественный царь, у которого был великолепный сад, наполненный самыми красивыми цветами и редкими деревьями. Гордостью сада была Жар-птица, магическое существо с перьями, которые светились, как пламя. Каждую ночь Жар-птица прилетала в сад, чтобы полакомиться золотыми яблоками, но никто не мог ее поймать. Младший сын царя, князь Иван, решил отправиться в путь, чтобы поймать Жар-птицу. С помощью мудрого волка Иван преодолел множество испытаний, в том числе сразился с злым колдуном и спас принцессу. В конце концов, Иван поймал Жар-птицу и привел ее к своему отцу, заработав свое место в качестве законного наследника трона.

story.en: Vasilisa, a kind and beautiful girl, lived with her wicked stepmother and stepsisters. Before her mother died, she gave Vasilisa a magical doll that would protect her from harm. The stepmother sent Vasilisa into the dark forest to fetch fire from Baba Yaga, the fearsome witch. With the help of her magical doll, Vasilisa completed the impossible tasks Baba Yaga set for her. Impressed but angry, Baba Yaga let Vasilisa go, and she returned home with a skull lantern that burned her stepfamily to ashes. Vasilisa later became a skilled weaver and eventually married the Tsar.
story.РУ: Василиса, добрая и красивая девушка, жила со своей злой мачехой и сводными сестрами. Перед смертью мать подарила Василисе волшебную куклу, которая защищала ее от бед. Мачеха отправила Василису в темный лес за огнем от Бабы-Яги, страшной ведьмы. С помощью своей волшебной куклы Василиса выполнила все невозможные задания, которые ей дала Баба-Яга. Ведьма, впечатленная, но разозленная, отпустила Василису, и та вернулась домой с черепом-фонарем, который сжег ее злую семью. Василиса позже стала искусной ткачихой и в конце концов вышла замуж за царя.

story.en: An elderly couple, who had no children, built a snow girl in the midst of a harsh winter. Miraculously, the snow girl, Snegurochka, came to life and became their daughter. She was a beautiful and gentle child but longed to experience the warmth of summer. As spring arrived and the weather warmed, Snegurochka began to feel sad. One day, while playing with other children, she melted away in the heat of the sun, leaving her parents heartbroken but grateful for the brief joy she had brought to their lives.
story.РУ: Пожилая пара, у которых не было детей, слепила снежную девочку посреди суровой зимы. Чудесным образом снежная девочка, Снегурочка, ожила и стала их дочерью. Она была красивым и нежным ребенком, но мечтала почувствовать тепло лета. Когда наступила весна и погода потеплела, Снегурочка начала грустить. Однажды, играя с другими детьми, она растаяла под солнечными лучами, оставив своих родителей с разбитыми сердцами, но благодарными за ту краткую радость, которую она принесла в их жизнь.

story.en: Prince Ivan set out on a journey to capture the magical Firebird for his father, the Tsar. Along the way, he encountered a talking Gray Wolf, who offered to help him. The wolf carried Ivan on its back and guided him to the Firebird, the Horse with the Golden Mane, and the beautiful Princess Elena. With the wolf's help, Ivan successfully completed each task, but his jealous brothers killed him and took the treasures for themselves. The Gray Wolf revived Ivan with the Water of Life, and Ivan returned to expose his brothers' treachery, eventually marrying Elena and inheriting the throne.
story.РУ: Князь Иван отправился в путешествие, чтобы поймать волшебную Жар-птицу для своего отца, царя. По дороге он встретил говорящего Серого Волка, который предложил свою помощь. Волк перенес Ивана на спине и направил его к Жар-птице, Коню с Золотой Гривой и прекрасной принцессе Елене. С помощью Волка Иван успешно выполнил каждое задание, но его завистливые братья убили его и забрали сокровища себе. Серый Волк воскресил Ивана Водой Жизни, и Иван вернулся, чтобы разоблачить предательство своих братьев, в конечном итоге женившись на Елене и унаследовав трон.

story.en: The youngest son of a Tsar, Prince Ivan, was given an arrow and told to marry the girl who found it. His arrow was found by a frog, which he reluctantly married. However, the frog was actually a beautiful princess named Vasilisa, cursed by an evil sorcerer. Vasilisa's wisdom and magic helped Ivan overcome many challenges, and she eventually revealed her true form to him. Despite this, Ivan burned her frog skin, breaking the curse but causing Vasilisa to disappear. Ivan went on a long journey to find her, facing many dangers, and they were finally reunited, breaking the curse forever.
story.РУ: Младший сын царя, князь Иван, получил стрелу и был приказан жениться на девушке, которая ее найдет. Его стрелу нашла лягушка, на которой он неохотно женился. Однако лягушка на самом деле была прекрасной принцессой по имени Василиса, проклятой злым колдуном. Мудрость и магия Василисы помогли Ивану преодолеть множество испытаний, и она в конце концов раскрыла ему свою истинную форму. Несмотря на это, Иван сжег ее лягушачью кожу, сняв проклятие, но Василиса исчезла. Иван отправился в долгое путешествие, чтобы найти ее, преодолев множество опасностей, и они наконец воссоединились, окончательно сняв проклятие.

story.en: In a small village in Mexico, there was once a beautiful woman named Maria who was deeply in love with a nobleman. They had two children together, but the nobleman eventually left Maria for another woman. Devastated and consumed by jealousy, Maria took her children to the river and, in a moment of madness, drowned them. Realizing what she had done, she was overcome with grief and wandered the riverbanks, wailing for her lost children. From that day on, her spirit, known as La Llorona, haunted the area, crying and searching for her children. It is said that if you hear her wailing, you should be careful, as she might mistake you for one of her children and take you with her to the afterlife.
story.es: En un pequeño pueblo de México, había una vez una hermosa mujer llamada María que estaba profundamente enamorada de un noble. Tuvieron dos hijos juntos, pero el noble finalmente dejó a María por otra mujer. Devastada y consumida por los celos, María llevó a sus hijos al río y, en un momento de locura, los ahogó. Al darse cuenta de lo que había hecho, fue invadida por el dolor y vagó por las orillas del río, llorando por sus hijos perdidos. Desde ese día, su espíritu, conocido como La Llorona, rondaba por la zona, llorando y buscando a sus hijos. Se dice que si escuchas su llanto, debes tener cuidado, ya que podría confundirte con uno de sus hijos y llevarte con ella al más allá.

story.en: Rodrigo Díaz de Vivar, known as El Cid, was a noble warrior in medieval Spain. Banished by King Alfonso VI, El Cid led a group of loyal followers in battles against the Moors, becoming a legendary hero. His courage, honor, and skill in battle earned him the title 'El Cid Campeador,' meaning 'The Champion.' Despite his exile, El Cid continued to fight for his country, eventually capturing the city of Valencia. His legacy lived on as a symbol of Spanish chivalry, and his tale became one of the most celebrated in Spanish folklore.
story.es: Rodrigo Díaz de Vivar, conocido como El Cid, fue un noble guerrero en la España medieval. Desterrado por el Rey Alfonso VI, El Cid lideró a un grupo de leales seguidores en batallas contra los moros, convirtiéndose en un héroe legendario. Su valentía, honor y habilidad en la batalla le valieron el título de 'El Cid Campeador,' que significa 'El Campeón.' A pesar de su exilio, El Cid continuó luchando por su país, capturando finalmente la ciudad de Valencia. Su legado perduró como un símbolo de la caballería española, y su historia se convirtió en una de las más celebradas en el folclore español.

story.en: Don Quixote, an aging gentleman from La Mancha, became obsessed with tales of chivalry and knights. He decided to become a knight-errant himself, taking up the name Don Quixote de la Mancha. With his loyal squire, Sancho Panza, Don Quixote set out on a series of adventures, fighting windmills he believed to be giants and mistaking inns for castles. Though often misguided and delusional, Don Quixote's idealism and determination made him a beloved figure in Spanish folklore, representing the tension between reality and imagination.
story.es: Don Quijote, un caballero mayor de La Mancha, se obsesionó con los cuentos de caballería y caballeros. Decidió convertirse en un caballero andante él mismo, tomando el nombre de Don Quijote de la Mancha. Con su leal escudero, Sancho Panza, Don Quijote emprendió una serie de aventuras, luchando contra molinos de viento que creía ser gigantes y confundiendo posadas con castillos. Aunque a menudo era mal guiado y delirante, el idealismo y la determinación de Don Quijote lo convirtieron en una figura querida en el folclore español, representando la tensión entre la realidad y la imaginación.

story.en: El Coco is a mythical creature from Spanish and Latin American folklore, used by parents to scare children into good behavior. It is said that El Coco, also known as 'The Bogeyman,' comes at night to take away children who misbehave or refuse to sleep. The creature is often described as a shapeless figure or a hairy monster that hides under beds or in closets, waiting to snatch naughty children. The legend of El Coco serves as a cautionary tale, teaching children the importance of obedience and discipline.
story.es: El Coco es una criatura mítica del folclore español y latinoamericano, usada por los padres para asustar a los niños y lograr que se comporten bien. Se dice que El Coco, también conocido como 'El Hombre del Saco,' viene por la noche para llevarse a los niños que se portan mal o se niegan a dormir. La criatura se describe a menudo como una figura amorfa o un monstruo peludo que se esconde bajo las camas o en los armarios, esperando para atrapar a los niños traviesos. La leyenda de El Coco sirve como un cuento de advertencia, enseñando a los niños la importancia de la obediencia y la disciplina.

story.en: La Giralda is the famous bell tower of the Seville Cathedral in Spain, originally built as a minaret during the Almohad dynasty. According to legend, a great sorcerer named Ahmed built La Giralda to be so tall and magnificent that it could touch the sky. He used powerful magic to make the tower withstand any disaster. When the Christians reconquered Seville, they decided to preserve the tower, adding the belfry and Christian symbols. La Giralda became a symbol of the city and a testament to the blend of Christian and Muslim heritage in Spain.
story.es: La Giralda es la famosa torre campanario de la Catedral de Sevilla en España, originalmente construida como un minarete durante la dinastía almohade. Según la leyenda, un gran hechicero llamado Ahmed construyó La Giralda para que fuera tan alta y magnífica que pudiera tocar el cielo. Utilizó una poderosa magia para hacer que la torre resistiera cualquier desastre. Cuando los cristianos reconquistaron Sevilla, decidieron conservar la torre, añadiendo el campanario y símbolos cristianos. La Giralda se convirtió en un símbolo de la ciudad y en un testimonio de la mezcla de herencia cristiana y musulmana en España.

story.en: Once upon a time, there was a poor miller who had a beautiful daughter. In an attempt to impress the king, the miller lied and said that his daughter could spin straw into gold. The king, intrigued, summoned the daughter to his castle and locked her in a room filled with straw, demanding that she spin it into gold by morning. The girl was distraught, knowing she could not perform such a task, when suddenly, a strange little man appeared and offered to spin the straw into gold in exchange for something of value. The girl gave him her necklace, and the little man kept his promise. The next night, the king demanded more gold, and the little man returned, this time asking for the girl's ring. On the third night, the king demanded even more gold, and the little man asked for the girl's firstborn child in exchange. Desperate, the girl agreed. When she later became queen and had a child, the little man returned to claim his prize. However, he agreed to spare the child if the queen could guess his name. After many attempts, the queen finally discovered the little man's name—Rumpelstiltskin—and he disappeared in a fit of rage, never to be seen again.
story.de: Es war einmal ein armer Müller, der eine schöne Tochter hatte. Um den König zu beeindrucken, log der Müller und sagte, seine Tochter könne Stroh zu Gold spinnen. Der König, neugierig geworden, rief die Tochter in sein Schloss und sperrte sie in ein Zimmer voller Stroh, mit der Forderung, es bis zum Morgen in Gold zu verwandeln. Das Mädchen war verzweifelt, da sie wusste, dass sie diese Aufgabe nicht erfüllen konnte, als plötzlich ein seltsamer kleiner Mann erschien und anbot, das Stroh gegen etwas Wertvolles in Gold zu spinnen. Das Mädchen gab ihm ihre Halskette, und der kleine Mann hielt sein Versprechen. In der nächsten Nacht verlangte der König noch mehr Gold, und der kleine Mann kehrte zurück und forderte dieses Mal den Ring des Mädchens. In der dritten Nacht verlangte der König noch mehr Gold, und der kleine Mann verlangte im Gegenzug das erstgeborene Kind des Mädchens. Verzweifelt stimmte das Mädchen zu. Als sie später Königin wurde und ein Kind bekam, kehrte der kleine Mann zurück, um seinen Preis einzufordern. Er versprach jedoch, das Kind zu verschonen, wenn die Königin seinen Namen erraten könnte. Nach vielen Versuchen entdeckte die Königin schließlich den Namen des kleinen Mannes – Rumpelstilzchen – und er verschwand vor Wut, nie wieder gesehen zu werden.

story.en: Hansel and Gretel were the children of a poor woodcutter. When a great famine struck the land, their wicked stepmother convinced their father to abandon them in the forest. Hansel and Gretel left a trail of breadcrumbs to find their way back, but birds ate the crumbs, leaving them lost. They stumbled upon a house made of candy and gingerbread, owned by a wicked witch who lured them inside to eat them. However, the clever children outwitted the witch, pushing her into her own oven and escaping with her treasure. They returned home to their father, who had since regretted his actions, and they all lived happily ever after.
story.de: Hänsel und Gretel waren die Kinder eines armen Holzfällers. Als eine große Hungersnot das Land heimsuchte, überzeugte ihre böse Stiefmutter ihren Vater, sie im Wald auszusetzen. Hänsel und Gretel hinterließen eine Spur aus Brotkrumen, um den Weg zurückzufinden, doch die Vögel fraßen die Krumen auf, sodass sie sich verirrten. Sie stießen auf ein Haus aus Süßigkeiten und Lebkuchen, das einer bösen Hexe gehörte, die sie hereinlockte, um sie zu fressen. Doch die cleveren Kinder überlisteten die Hexe, schoben sie in ihren eigenen Ofen und entkamen mit ihrem Schatz. Sie kehrten zu ihrem Vater zurück, der seine Tat inzwischen bereut hatte, und sie lebten glücklich bis ans Ende ihrer Tage.

story.en: The town of Hamelin was overrun with rats, and the townspeople were desperate for a solution. A mysterious piper dressed in multicolored clothing appeared, offering to rid the town of its rats in exchange for a large sum of money. The townspeople agreed, and the piper played his magical flute, leading the rats into the Weser River, where they drowned. However, the townspeople refused to pay the piper. In revenge, the piper played his flute again, this time leading the town's children into a cave, where they disappeared forever. The legend serves as a warning about the consequences of breaking promises.
story.de: Die Stadt Hameln wurde von Ratten überrannt, und die Bürger waren verzweifelt auf der Suche nach einer Lösung. Ein mysteriöser Pfeifer, gekleidet in bunte Kleidung, erschien und bot an, die Stadt gegen eine große Geldsumme von den Ratten zu befreien. Die Bürger stimmten zu, und der Pfeifer spielte auf seiner magischen Flöte, führte die Ratten in die Weser, wo sie ertranken. Die Bürger weigerten sich jedoch, den Pfeifer zu bezahlen. Aus Rache spielte der Pfeifer erneut auf seiner Flöte und führte diesmal die Kinder der Stadt in eine Höhle, wo sie für immer verschwanden. Die Legende dient als Warnung vor den Folgen gebrochener Versprechen.

story.en: Snow White was a beautiful princess whose stepmother, the Evil Queen, was jealous of her beauty. The Queen ordered a huntsman to take Snow White into the forest and kill her, but the huntsman couldn't bring himself to do it and let her go. Snow White found refuge in the home of seven dwarfs, who welcomed her. The Queen discovered that Snow White was still alive and attempted to kill her with a poisoned apple. Snow White fell into a deep sleep, but a prince who had fallen in love with her broke the curse with a kiss. Snow White awoke, and they lived happily ever after.
story.de: Schneewittchen war eine schöne Prinzessin, deren Stiefmutter, die böse Königin, neidisch auf ihre Schönheit war. Die Königin befahl einem Jäger, Schneewittchen in den Wald zu bringen und sie zu töten, doch der Jäger konnte es nicht über sich bringen und ließ sie gehen. Schneewittchen fand Zuflucht im Haus von sieben Zwergen, die sie willkommen hießen. Die Königin entdeckte, dass Schneewittchen noch am Leben war, und versuchte, sie mit einem vergifteten Apfel zu töten. Schneewittchen fiel in einen tiefen Schlaf, aber ein Prinz, der sich in sie verliebt hatte, brach den Fluch mit einem Kuss. Schneewittchen erwachte, und sie lebten glücklich bis ans Ende ihrer Tage.

story.en: A donkey, a dog, a cat, and a rooster, all old and unwanted by their owners, decided to run away and become musicians in the town of Bremen. On their journey, they came across a band of robbers living in a house. The animals stood on each other's backs and made a terrible noise, scaring the robbers away. The animals moved into the house and lived together happily, never reaching Bremen but finding a new life free from their past hardships.
story.de: Ein Esel, ein Hund, eine Katze und ein Hahn, alle alt und von ihren Besitzern unerwünscht, beschlossen, wegzulaufen und in der Stadt Bremen Musiker zu werden. Auf ihrer Reise stießen sie auf eine Räuberbande, die in einem Haus lebte. Die Tiere stellten sich aufeinander und machten ein schreckliches Geräusch, das die Räuber in die Flucht schlug. Die Tiere zogen in das Haus ein und lebten glücklich zusammen, erreichten niemals Bremen, fanden aber ein neues Leben frei von ihren früheren Härten.

story.en: Once upon a time, a wealthy merchant had three daughters. The youngest, named Belle, was kind and beautiful. One day, the merchant lost all his wealth and was forced to live in the countryside with his daughters. During a trip to regain his fortune, the merchant became lost in a forest and stumbled upon a grand castle. Inside, he found food and shelter, but as he left, he picked a rose for Belle. This angered the castle's owner, a fearsome Beast, who demanded the merchant's life in exchange for the rose. To save her father, Belle offered to take his place. As she lived with the Beast, she discovered that he was not as terrifying as he seemed and grew fond of him. Eventually, Belle's love broke the spell that had turned the Beast into a monster, revealing him to be a handsome prince. They lived happily ever after, teaching that true beauty lies within.
story.fr: Il était une fois un riche marchand qui avait trois filles. La plus jeune, nommée Belle, était gentille et belle. Un jour, le marchand perdit toute sa fortune et fut contraint de vivre à la campagne avec ses filles. Lors d'un voyage pour retrouver sa fortune, le marchand se perdit dans une forêt et tomba sur un grand château. À l'intérieur, il trouva de la nourriture et un abri, mais en partant, il cueillit une rose pour Belle. Cela mit en colère le propriétaire du château, une Bête redoutable, qui exigea la vie du marchand en échange de la rose. Pour sauver son père, Belle proposa de prendre sa place. En vivant avec la Bête, elle découvrit qu'il n'était pas aussi terrifiant qu'il en avait l'air et s'attacha à lui. Finalement, l'amour de Belle brisa le sort qui avait transformé la Bête en monstre, révélant un prince beau et charmant. Ils vécurent heureux pour toujours, enseignant que la véritable beauté réside à l'intérieur.

story.en: A little girl named Red Riding Hood was sent by her mother to visit her grandmother, bringing her a basket of food. On her way, she met a wolf who asked where she was going. Red Riding Hood innocently told him, and the wolf hurried to the grandmother's house, ate her, and disguised himself in her clothes. When Red Riding Hood arrived, she noticed that her 'grandmother' looked different. The wolf then tried to eat Red Riding Hood, but a passing hunter heard her cries and came to the rescue, killing the wolf and saving both Red Riding Hood and her grandmother.
story.fr: Une petite fille nommée Chaperon Rouge fut envoyée par sa mère pour rendre visite à sa grand-mère, lui apportant un panier de nourriture. En chemin, elle rencontra un loup qui lui demanda où elle allait. Chaperon Rouge lui répondit innocemment, et le loup se précipita chez la grand-mère, la mangea, et se déguisa en elle. Lorsque Chaperon Rouge arriva, elle remarqua que sa 'grand-mère' avait un aspect différent. Le loup tenta alors de manger Chaperon Rouge, mais un chasseur qui passait par là entendit ses cris et vint à sa rescousse, tuant le loup et sauvant à la fois Chaperon Rouge et sa grand-mère.

story.en: Cinderella was a kind and beautiful girl who lived with her cruel stepmother and stepsisters. They forced her to do all the housework and treated her poorly. One day, the prince of the kingdom announced a grand ball, and Cinderella's stepsisters were invited, but she was not. However, Cinderella's Fairy Godmother appeared and magically transformed her rags into a beautiful gown, complete with glass slippers. She went to the ball and danced with the prince, but had to leave before midnight when the magic wore off. In her haste, she left behind one glass slipper. The prince searched the kingdom for the girl who fit the slipper, and when he found Cinderella, they were married and lived happily ever after.
story.fr: Cendrillon était une fille gentille et belle qui vivait avec sa cruelle belle-mère et ses demi-sœurs. Elles la forçaient à faire tout le ménage et la traitaient mal. Un jour, le prince du royaume annonça un grand bal, et les demi-sœurs de Cendrillon furent invitées, mais pas elle. Cependant, la marraine fée de Cendrillon apparut et transforma magiquement ses haillons en une belle robe, complétée par des pantoufles de verre. Elle alla au bal et dansa avec le prince, mais elle dut partir avant minuit lorsque la magie s'éteignit. Dans sa hâte, elle laissa derrière elle une pantoufle de verre. Le prince parcourut le royaume à la recherche de la fille qui pourrait enfiler la pantoufle, et quand il trouva Cendrillon, ils se marièrent et vécurent heureux pour toujours.

story.en: Bluebeard was a wealthy and powerful man known for his blue-colored beard. He married many women, but they all mysteriously disappeared. When he married his latest wife, he gave her the keys to all his rooms but forbade her from entering one in particular. Curiosity got the better of her, and she opened the forbidden door, discovering the bodies of Bluebeard's previous wives. Terrified, she managed to delay Bluebeard's wrath until her brothers arrived and killed him, saving her from his murderous intentions.
story.fr: Barbe Bleue était un homme riche et puissant, connu pour sa barbe bleue. Il épousa de nombreuses femmes, mais elles disparurent toutes mystérieusement. Lorsqu'il épousa sa dernière femme, il lui donna les clés de toutes ses chambres mais lui interdit d'entrer dans une en particulier. La curiosité l'emporta sur elle, et elle ouvrit la porte interdite, découvrant les corps des précédentes épouses de Barbe Bleue. Terrifiée, elle réussit à retarder la colère de Barbe Bleue jusqu'à ce que ses frères arrivent et le tuent, la sauvant ainsi de ses intentions meurtrières.

story.en: A king and queen, after many years of longing, had a beautiful daughter. To celebrate, they held a grand feast and invited fairies to bless the child. However, one fairy, who was not invited, cursed the princess, predicting that she would prick her finger on a spindle and die. Another fairy altered the curse so that the princess would only fall into a deep sleep for 100 years. The curse came true, but after 100 years, a prince discovered the sleeping princess and kissed her, breaking the spell. They married and lived happily ever after.
story.fr: Un roi et une reine, après de nombreuses années d'attente, eurent une belle fille. Pour célébrer, ils organisèrent un grand festin et invitèrent des fées pour bénir l'enfant. Cependant, une fée, qui n'avait pas été invitée, maudit la princesse, prédisant qu'elle se piquerait le doigt sur un fuseau et mourrait. Une autre fée modifia la malédiction pour que la princesse ne tombe que dans un profond sommeil de 100 ans. La malédiction se réalisa, mais après 100 ans, un prince découvrit la princesse endormie et la réveilla d'un baiser, rompant ainsi le sort. Ils se marièrent et vécurent heureux pour toujours.

story.en: Tsar Saltan married a beautiful woman, and they soon had a son named Gvidon. However, the Tsar's wicked sisters-in-law were jealous and conspired to have the Tsarina and her son cast into the sea. The mother and child survived and washed ashore on a magical island. Gvidon grew up strong and brave, eventually saving a swan that transformed into a beautiful princess. With the help of the magical creatures on the island, Gvidon returned to his father's kingdom and revealed the truth. The wicked sisters were punished, and Gvidon and his mother were reunited with Tsar Saltan, living happily ever after.
story.ru: Царь Салтан женился на прекрасной женщине, и вскоре у них родился сын по имени Гвидон. Однако злые золовки царя завидовали и замышляли бросить царицу и её сына в море. Мать и ребенок выжили и оказались на волшебном острове. Гвидон вырос сильным и храбрым, однажды он спас лебедя, который превратился в прекрасную принцессу. С помощью волшебных существ на острове Гвидон вернулся в царство своего отца и раскрыл правду. Злые сестры были наказаны, а Гвидон и его мать воссоединились с царем Салтаном и жили долго и счастливо.

title: The Feather of Finist the Falcon

story.en: A poor merchant had three daughters, and the youngest, Maria, was the most beautiful and kind. One day, Maria asked her father to bring her the feather of Finist the Falcon, a magical bird. The father found the feather, and when Maria held it, Finist the Falcon appeared, transforming into a handsome man at night. They fell in love, but her jealous sisters ruined their happiness by driving Finist away. Maria embarked on a perilous journey to find him, facing many challenges. In the end, she found Finist, and her love broke the spell that bound him. They married and lived in happiness.
story.ru: У бедного купца было три дочери, и младшая, Мария, была самой красивой и доброй. Однажды Мария попросила отца принести ей перо Финиста Ясного Сокола, волшебной птицы. Отец нашел перо, и когда Мария взяла его в руки, Финист появился, превращаясь ночью в красивого мужчину. Они полюбили друг друга, но её завистливые сестры разрушили их счастье, прогнав Финиста. Мария отправилась в опасное путешествие, чтобы найти его, преодолевая множество испытаний. В конце концов, она нашла Финиста, и её любовь разрушила заклятие, которое связывало его. Они поженились и жили счастливо.

story.en: A poor peasant had a clever daughter who could solve any problem. One day, the Tsar set a challenge: to come to his palace neither on foot nor on horseback, neither dressed nor undressed, and neither bringing a gift nor empty-handed. The clever girl arrived riding a goat, wrapped in a fishing net, and carrying a bird in one hand. The Tsar was so impressed by her wisdom that he made her his advisor. The girl used her wit to outsmart the Tsar's greedy ministers, proving that intelligence and cleverness could triumph over wealth and power.
story.ru: У бедного крестьянина была умная дочь, которая могла решить любую задачу. Однажды царь дал задание: прийти к нему во дворец ни пешком, ни верхом, ни одетой, ни раздетой, и не неся подарок, но и не с пустыми руками. Умная девочка пришла, верхом на козе, завернувшись в рыболовную сеть и держа в руке птицу. Царь был настолько впечатлен её мудростью, что сделал её своим советником. Девушка использовала свой ум, чтобы перехитрить жадных министров царя, доказав, что разум и смекалка могут победить богатство и власть.

story.en: Danila, a talented stone carver, became obsessed with creating the perfect piece of art. He heard of a mythical Stone Flower that could teach him the secrets of his craft. Danila journeyed to the realm of the Mistress of the Copper Mountain, who guarded the Stone Flower. She allowed him to see the flower, but in exchange, he had to stay with her forever. However, Danila's love for his fiancée, Katya, was stronger, and with her love and courage, he managed to return home. The Mistress granted him mastery over stone but allowed him to leave her domain, reuniting him with Katya.
story.ru: Данила, талантливый камнерез, одержимый созданием идеального произведения искусства. Он услышал о мифическом Каменном Цветке, который мог бы научить его секретам ремесла. Данила отправился в царство Хозяйки Медной горы, которая охраняла Каменный Цветок. Она позволила ему увидеть цветок, но взамен он должен был остаться с ней навсегда. Однако любовь Данилы к его невесте Кате была сильнее, и с её помощью он смог вернуться домой. Хозяйка даровала ему мастерство в работе с камнем, но позволила покинуть её владения, воссоединив его с Катей.

title: The Tale of the Golden Cockerel

story.en: Tsar Dodon ruled his kingdom with fear but was always worried about enemies. An astrologer gave him a golden cockerel that would crow to warn of danger. In return, the astrologer asked for any favor he desired. The cockerel served the Tsar well until one day it crowed, signaling danger from the east. Tsar Dodon led his army but found nothing. On his return, the astrologer asked for the Tsar's bride as his reward. Angry, Tsar Dodon struck the astrologer, but the golden cockerel pecked the Tsar to death, fulfilling the astrologer's prophecy that greed and broken promises lead to downfall.
story.ru: Царь Додон правил своим королевством со страхом, но всегда беспокоился об опасности. Астролог дал ему золотого петушка, который должен был кукарекать, чтобы предупредить об опасности. В обмен астролог попросил любую услугу, которую пожелает. Петушок хорошо служил царю, пока однажды он не закукарекал, сигнализируя об опасности с востока. Царь Додон повел свое войско, но ничего не нашел. Возвращаясь, астролог попросил в качестве награды невесту царя. Разъяренный, царь Додон ударил астролога, но золотой петушок клюнул царя насмерть, исполнив пророчество астролога, что жадность и нарушенные обещания ведут к падению.

story.en: In Toledo, Spain, there was a well known as El Pozo Amargo, or The Bitter Well. The legend tells of a young Christian girl and a Jewish boy who fell deeply in love. Their love was forbidden by their families, and one night, the girl was found dead at the bottom of the well, having thrown herself in out of despair. Her lover was so heartbroken that he poisoned the well, cursing it so that all who drank from it would taste the bitterness of their forbidden love. The well became a symbol of tragic love and loss, and the story was passed down through generations.
story.es: En Toledo, España, había un pozo conocido como El Pozo Amargo. La leyenda cuenta de una joven cristiana y un joven judío que se enamoraron profundamente. Su amor estaba prohibido por sus familias, y una noche, la chica fue encontrada muerta en el fondo del pozo, habiéndose arrojado allí por desesperación. Su amante estaba tan desconsolado que envenenó el pozo, maldiciéndolo para que todos los que bebieran de él sintieran la amargura de su amor prohibido. El pozo se convirtió en un símbolo de amor trágico y pérdida, y la historia se transmitió a través de generaciones.

story.en: Sant Jordi, or Saint George, is the patron saint of Catalonia. According to legend, a dragon terrorized the town of Montblanc, demanding human sacrifices. When the king's daughter was chosen as the next victim, Sant Jordi appeared on a white horse, fought the dragon, and killed it with his lance. From the dragon's blood, a rose bush grew, and Sant Jordi gave the princess a single red rose. To this day, Sant Jordi's Day is celebrated in Catalonia with the exchange of roses and books, symbolizing love and culture.
story.es: Sant Jordi, o San Jorge, es el santo patrón de Cataluña. Según la leyenda, un dragón aterrorizaba la ciudad de Montblanc, exigiendo sacrificios humanos. Cuando la hija del rey fue elegida como la próxima víctima, Sant Jordi apareció en un caballo blanco, luchó contra el dragón y lo mató con su lanza. De la sangre del dragón creció un rosal, y Sant Jordi le dio a la princesa una sola rosa roja. Hasta el día de hoy, el Día de Sant Jordi se celebra en Cataluña con el intercambio de rosas y libros, simbolizando el amor y la cultura.

story.en: In the region of Murcia, Spain, there is a legend of La Encantada, a beautiful Moorish princess who was cursed to remain hidden in a cave, guarding her father's treasures. The curse could only be broken by a man who was pure of heart and could resist her beauty. Many men tried to rescue her, but they all succumbed to her charms and were turned to stone. It is said that La Encantada still waits in her cave, and on the night of San Juan, she appears to lure new victims, hoping one day to find her true savior.
story.es: En la región de Murcia, España, hay una leyenda de La Encantada, una hermosa princesa mora que fue maldita para permanecer oculta en una cueva, guardando los tesoros de su padre. La maldición solo podía ser rota por un hombre que fuera puro de corazón y pudiera resistir su belleza. Muchos hombres intentaron rescatarla, pero todos sucumbieron a sus encantos y fueron convertidos en piedra. Se dice que La Encantada todavía espera en su cueva, y en la noche de San Juan, aparece para atraer nuevas víctimas, esperando un día encontrar a su verdadero salvador.

title: The Legend of the Lovers of Teruel

story.en: In the city of Teruel, there lived two lovers, Diego and Isabel, who were deeply in love but of different social standings.
